para.paratext: Fed. R. Evid. 406 allows third parties to prove another person's habit[1] and Georgia's new O.C.G.A. § 24-4-406 tracks the federal rule.

Evidence of the habit of a person or of the routine practice of an organization, whether corroborated or not and regardless of the presence of eyewitnesses, is relevant to prove that the conduct of the person or organization on a particular occasion was in conformity with such habit or routine practice.

Habit as used here includes usual custom or course of conduct. Where a person usually did a particular thing in a particular way, evidence of such conduct will be admissible to prove that the usual procedure was followed on the occasion in question.[2] However, evidence of habit should be that the conduct is almost automatic.

Evidence of a routine practice may be admissible under Rule 406 to prove the routine practices of an organization or company; however, it is for the jury to determine if the routine practice was followed with regard to the particular facts of each case.[3]

A witness may state the usual custom or habit employed by himself or his business to perform a particular act and that this act took place on the occasion in question.[4] Thus, an office's usual custom or habit in mailing letters may be shown to prove that a specific letter was mailed.[5]
In Stripling v. Godfrey,[6] testimony concerning decedent's habit of drunkenly stepping in front of approaching vehicles was relevant to show whether she was negligent.

However, in Battle v. Kavalski,[7] the Georgia Court of Appeals upheld the trial court's exclusion of evidence that the defendant provided alcohol to the plaintiff's deceased minor son approximately six times a month because the evidence of past alcohol consumption did not “provide any indication as to whether such conduct [by the defendant] was fixed and uniform so as to be habitual.”

The Court of Appeals upheld the exclusion of a driver's testimony regarding how she often drove on a particular curve where a deadly collision occurred. The court reasoned that how an individual drives, even on a specific curve, is subject to countless variables each time the person drives, and therefore is not the type of evidence contemplated by the General Assembly to be admissible pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 24-6-406.[8]

See, e.g., Loughan v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co., 749 F.2d 1519, 17 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 141, 40 Fed. R. Serv. 2d 1243 (11th Cir. 1985) (testimony from previous employer and supervisor established drinking habit).

Wood v. First Nat. Bank of Commerce, 167 Ga. App. 202, 305 S.E.2d 852, 37 U.C.C. Rep. Serv. 375 (1983); Thomas v. Newnan Hosp., 185 Ga. App. 764, 365 S.E.2d 859 (1988). But see Feinberg v. Durga, 189 Ga. App. 733, 736, 377 S.E.2d 33 (1988), which limited testimony about other's habit to cases in which the actor had died.
Turfgrass Group, Inc. v. Georgia Cold Storage Co., 346 Ga. App. 659, 816 S.E.2d 716, 96 U.C.C. Rep. Serv. 2d 148 (2018).
